Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Software Infrastructure for Cloud Simulation and Strategic Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The availability of large-scale computing provided by platforms reduces the costs of exploiting compute-intensive analysis in support of strategic decision making. Computational infrastructure developed by the project team provides middleware that shields the user from such concerns, and thus can provide a valuable gateway to the cloud for simulation-based decision support systems. The approach is founded on an emerging methodology for strategic reasoning based on empirical game-theoretic analysis (EGTA). EGTA combines massive simulation and other empirical methods with concepts from game theory to support decisions that anticipate strategies and reactions from other agents (e.g., competitors, customers) in a complex environment. The approach aligns the simplicity of agent-based modeling with the principled analytic basis of game theory. The technology developed promises to dramatically increase the scale and fidelity of EGTA studies, extending the scope of game-theoretic reasoning from stylized domains to real-world problems.

Many problem environments faced by firms, individuals, and society are fundamentally strategic, in that the outcome of one agent's action depends pivotally on the choices of others. Improving strategic decision making in complex domains offers benefits for many economically important applications, for example, supply chain risk management, infrastructure and location planning, and technology adoption and standardization. Facilities developed in this project will broaden access to large-scale distributed computing resources, leading to significant efficiencies in utilization of computational infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored the commercial potential for NSF-supported research in strategic reasoning. Strategic reasoning is the analysis of decisions in contexts where the decisions of other actors (e.g., competitors or customers in a market, adversaries in a security context) are pivotal in determining outcomes. In previous NSF research, the investigators developed a comprehensive methodology and associated computational infrastructure for analyzing strategic decisions using agent-based simulation models. An agent-based simulation allows the modeler to explore a complex scenario with interacting decision makers, when direct mathematical optimization is infeasible. The unique capabilities of the techniques developed include (1) management of large-scale simulation experiments on commodity parallel computing platforms (i.e., "cloud" resources), and (2) building models from the simulation data, and analyzing them using principles from game theory.

The central element of this project was participation in entrepreneurial traning through the I-Corps node at the Georgia Institute of Technology. As part of that training, our team conducted a comprehensive customer discovery process, in which we interviewed about one hundred relevant individuals from a wide variety of potential customer organizations. The process was invaluable both for evaluating specific hypotheses about the market potential of our technology, as well as developing our enterpreneurial skills. 

The ultimate result of the exercise was a decision not to pursue commercial development of the technology at this time. However, the lessons and skills learned have enabled us to improve the technology and make it more relevant for a broader set of applications. The experience has contributed significantly to our ongoing work developing the methods for applications in finance, cyber-security, and corporate strategy.
